Graphical abstract The development of energy-efficient catalysts for ammonia synthesis under mild conditions is crucial for reducing the energy demands and carbon footprint of the industrial Haber-Bosch process. In this study, we investigated ammonia synthesis via the associative Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism using B1-structured metal nitrides, focusing on manganese nitride (MnN) due to its low vacancy formation energy and potential as a metal-support interface. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations identified the MnN (100) facet as the most stable, with a nickel (Ni) nanowire implemented on the surface to facilitate H2 dissociation while surface nitrogen vacancies activate N2. A free energy diagram for Ni-MnN (100) at 350 °C was constructed and a dual-site microkinetic model was developed to determine reaction orders, apparent activation energies and the rate limiting step (RDS). To capture temperature-induced catalyst restructuring, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations and machine learning interatomic potentials (MLPs) were employed to improve the sampling of interfacial active sites over longer timescales. We found significant active site fluxionality leading to active site structural rearrangements that reduced vacancy formation energies. A hydrogen coverage analysis at reaction temperatures revealed coverage-dependent dynamic restructuring of Ni active sites, with lowered free energy change of the RDS that correlates with Ni p-Band center. MLPs were observed to predict coverage-dependent fluxionality with training data exclusive to high coverage regimes. By integrating DFT, AIMD, and MLP-based molecular dynamics, we established a computational framework for understanding dynamic metal-support interactions in transition metal nitride catalysts, demonstrating its applicability not only to ammonia synthesis under mild conditions but also to broader classes of supported catalysts and reactions. Keywords Ammonia Metal nitrides Ab initio molecular dynamics Density functional theory Machine learning force fields Machine learning interatomic potentials Data availability The data presented in the paper is available as a ZIP file on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14948592). 1 Introduction Ammonia production is among the most energy-intensive industrial processes worldwide which consumes over one percent of the global energy supply [1]. The significance of ammonia is highlighted by the multitude of its applications, such as being a source of fixed nitrogen for the fertilizer industry and, increasingly, as a hydrogen carrier and direct fuel since it can be stored and transported more easily than many other hydrogen-rich compounds [2–6]. These properties have led to heightened interest in the contribution of ammonia to sustainable energy systems, particularly in efforts to reduce carbon emissions while maintaining viable long-term energy storage options. The industrial production of ammonia has been dominated by the Haber-Bosch process since it was discovered in the 20th century which is characterized by elevated temperatures and pressure conditions and requires industrial plants to have a significant energy input to achieve a higher pass-per-conversion rate [7]. These high energy inputs are usually achieved by burning fossil fuels, which in turn increases the carbon footprint in the atmosphere because of increased CO2 emissions. Since the majority of the industrial ammonia production plants utilize fused iron (Fe) based catalysts and supported metal catalysts, the necessity for catalysts that can enable sustainable ammonia production is increasing [1,8]. Ammonia formation using nitrogen and hydrogen gases can undergo a dissociative or associative mechanism, depending on the catalyst chosen. The Fe-catalyzed dissociative Langmuir-Hinshelwood reaction mechanism for ammonia production from nitrogen and hydrogen gases proposed by Stoltze et al. consists of dissociative adsorption of nitrogen gas onto the surface, followed by the sequential hydrogenation of each of the individual nitrogen atoms to form ammonia [9]. Notably, the rate determining step for the dissociative mechanism is associated with the cleavage of the N ≡ N triple bond, which is energy intensive (bond breaking energy of 945 kJ/mol). Although Ru-based catalysts, which are inherently highly active in nature, have also been associated with the dissociative mechanism, their high cost limits their commercialization for industrial ammonia synthesis [10–14]. Thus, recent focus has shifted to metal nitride catalysts, which have been hypothesized to proceed via the dissociative Langmuir-Hinshelwood as well as the associative Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. In the case of the metal nitrides proceeding via the associative MvK mechanism, the lattice nitrogen reacts with hydrogen to form ammonia along with a surface nitrogen vacancy, similar to the MvK oxidation reaction observed in metal oxides [15–17]. The adsorption of N2 on the metal nitride surface can be facilitated by the formation of surface nitrogen vacancies. Subsequently, the adsorbed N2 can be sequentially hydrogenated to generate an ammonia molecule and replenish the lattice nitrogen vacancy. The associative MvK pathway circumvents the energy-intensive N ≡ N triple bond dissociation, an essential step in the dissociative reaction pathway, highlighting the potential of metal nitrides in conducting ammonia synthesis at mild temperature and pressure conditions [18,19]. Several metal nitrides have been identified as promising ammonia synthesis catalysts over the years, primarily being classified as binary and ternary metal nitrides. Ternary metal nitrides (MxM’yNz where M is Metal 1, M’ is Metal 2, N is Nitrogen, and x, y, z are the number of atoms of M, M’, and N respectively) as ammonia synthesis catalysts, particularly Co3Mo3N have been studied extensively through density functional theory (DFT) and experimental work [14,20–26]. Additionally, the advent of computational materials discovery and informatics tools has led to the discovery of novel thermodynamically stable ternary metal nitrides [27]. On a similar note, several binary metal nitride catalysts (MxNy where M is Metal, N is Nitrogen, and x, y are the number of atoms of M, and N respectively) have been studied in the literature, particularly those of molybdenum, manganese, vanadium, cerium, lanthanum [28–36]. The earliest work on binary metal nitrides was done by Mittasch et al., where molybdenum metal was used in ammonia synthesis using nitrogen and hydrogen gas, however, they detected minor amounts of molybdenum nitride during the catalysis, leading them to believe that nitrides of metals such as manganese, tungsten could be active ammonia synthesis catalysts [37]. While N2 is hypothesized to be activated via the formation of surface N vacancies, the activation of H2 can occur either on the metal nitride surface or on a nanoparticle on the metal nitride support. Recent work by Qu et al. demonstrated the ammonia synthesis on the MnN0.43 ( 1 1 ¯ 0 ) surface occurring via the associative MvK mechanism through a combined DFT and experimental analysis [38]. The authors attributed the activation of N2 to the surface N vacancy and the activation of H2 to the undercoordinated Mn metal atoms. Ye et al. studied ammonia synthesis in B1-structured (or rock salt structured) rare earth metal nitride ( 001 ) surfaces (LaN, CeN and YN) in the presence and absence of Ni loading [32,33]. In the presence of Ni loading, the activation of H2 on the nitride surfaces was attributed to the Ni atoms on the Ni8 nanocluster, while in the absence of Ni loading, the activation of H2 on the nitride surface was attributed to the formation of surface vacancies. Since Ni has a higher affinity for H and lower affinity for N − the Ni loaded metal nitrides act as a dual active site catalyst with the activation of N2 and H2 occurring at different sites [32]. Early transition metal nitrides have been shown to crystallize into rock salt structures, with nitrogen atoms often occupying the interstitial sites within the parent metal lattice. The incorporation of nitrogen expands the lattice, altering the nitride electronic structure such that it resembles those of noble metals. The altered electronic environment enhances their ability to activate and bond with nitrogen molecules, a critical step in ammonia synthesis – rendering them a cost-effective alternative to Fe-based and Ru-based catalysts, as well as catalyst supports due to their excellent electrical conductivity and chemical stability [39–41]. Ammonia synthesis via the associative Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism on binary metal nitrides has been shown to proceed by the activation of the lattice N and the adsorbed N2 at the surface N vacancy site. Ye et al. demonstrated that surface N vacancies on rare-earth metal nitrides serve as active sites for N2 activation via the associative ammonia synthesis mechanism, with lower vacancy formation energy (VFE) directly correlating with higher reaction rates [33]. Balasubramanian et al. reported that transition metal nitrides can exhibit a range of N vacancy formation energies, highlighting that under the right temperature and pressure conditions, nitrogen vacancy formation can be thermodynamically favourable [42]. Thus, to identify a metal nitride for our study that can give a high turnover rate at mild ammonia synthesis conditions, we focus on the highly symmetric B1-structured binary metal nitrides – including d-block transition metal nitrides (MnN, TaN, VN, NbN, TiN, ScN, ZrN, HfN) and rare-earth nitrides (CeN and YN), hereby collectively referred to as B1-structured metal nitrides or B1-MNs ( Fig. S1 ). For dual active site catalysts featuring metal nanoparticles (NPs) on supports, metal nanoclusters are often employed as computational models to approximate the ground state configuration of these metal NPs at low computational expense – while nanocluster models effectively capture metal-support interactions, these models suffer from finite size effects when they are scaled to represent larger nanoparticles and simulate higher adsorbate coverages. Zhao et al. demonstrated the modeling of an Au/MgO catalyst for the water gas shift reaction using Au nanowires as computational models for the Au NPs [43]. These quasi-one-dimensional nanowire models maintain the metallic character of the metal NP, and a continuous d-band because of the periodicity of the model, allowing us to extend the model to larger nanoparticles and subsequently explore kinetics under a wider range of adsorbate coverages [44–47]. Nanowire models also preserve the metal-support interface site configurations which may be crucial to modeling catalysis at these interfacial sites. While these computational models obtained from static DFT calculations offer invaluable insights into the catalyst structure, reaction mechanism, and the relevant kinetic parameters, they fall short of capturing the dynamic nature of active sites at reaction conditions, involving varying temperature, pressure and adsorbate coverages [48,49]. This dynamic behavior has been demonstrated experimentally; for instance, Ertl and colleagues showed through high-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy under controlled conditions that catalyst surfaces, such as Pt (110), undergo significant structural rearrangements even at room temperature [50,51]. Various computational techniques such as global optimization (GO) [52,53], kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) [54,55], and molecular dynamics (MD) [56,57] have been employed to gain atomic-level insights into the dynamic behavior of catalysts at reaction conditions. Alexandrova and colleagues used the GO method to study the isomerization process of metal nanocluster catalysts at reaction temperatures by considering the dynamic interconversion of energetically similar isomers, a phenomenon known as fluxionality [53,58–60]. Zhai et al. found the isomers of Pt7 nanocluster on α -alumina surface to exhibit fluxional behavior more rapidly at higher temperatures as compared to lower temperatures [61]. Subsequently, Baxter et al. studied the ethylene dehydrogenation of the fluxional Ptn (n = 4, 7, 8) clusters on α -alumina surface at different reaction conditions, and identified the Pt7 as the most catalytically active cluster as a result of the accessible isomer configurations at various temperature and adsorbate coverages [62]. Li et al. used a KMC model to simulate the reshaping of Pt NPs under a CO gas environment and found the formation of highly active atomic nanoclusters on the Pt (111) facets for the CO oxidation reaction [63]. In contrast to GO and KMC methods, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) can be used to study the structural dynamics of catalysts at different temperatures, by determining the interatomic forces through precise electronic structure calculations and sampling through a statistical ensemble [64]. However, AIMD is limited to small catalytic systems with hundreds of atoms and incurs a high computational cost. In recent years, machine learning interatomic potentials (MLPs) have shown great promise in developing precise and transferable machine learning force fields (MLFFs) trained on AIMD data. These MLFFs can then be deployed in classical MD packages to accelerate MD simulations while maintaining ab initio accuracy, allowing us to explore the dynamic behavior of catalytic active sites at different adsorbate coverages and reaction temperatures at a low computational cost [65–69]. While the entropy of the catalyst structures obtained from static DFT calculations are usually approximated using simplified partition function models such as the harmonic oscillator and hindered translator/rotor, the entropy of catalysts under dynamic reaction conditions cannot be calculated using these methods as a result of the anharmonic entropy effects on the free energy [49,70,71]. Recently, Gupta et al. demonstrated that AIMD-generated MLPs can be effectively incorporated into microkinetic models with quasi-harmonic corrections, providing a more accurate treatment of anharmonic effects on the adsorption free energy, leading to an improved prediction of reaction mechanisms and kinetic regimes [72]. Building on the experimental and theoretical insights discussed above, there remains a need to unravel the atomic-level interplay between the structural dynamics and reactivity of a dual active site catalyst at reaction conditions, which could allow closer comparisons with experimental kinetic measurements. In this work, we address the aforementioned challenges, by studying the associative MvK mechanism for ammonia synthesis in Ni-supported binary transition metal nitrides. We developed a dual active site catalyst by placing a Ni nanowire on rock salt MnN (100) surface, to probe the change in the vacancy formation energy for N vacancy sites at various distances from the nanowire. We used DFT to explore the associative MvK mechanism in Ni-MnN (100) from a thermodynamic and kinetic standpoint. We estimated reaction orders, and the apparent activation energy at 623 K using a dual active site microkinetic model under differential kinetic regime for the serial pathway, identifying the rate determining step using a generalized degree of rate control analysis. We performed AIMD on Ni-MnN (100) at 673 K and trained transferable MLPs that account for temperature-induced nanowire restructuring. We applied this workflow on H2-adsorbed Ni-MnN (100) surfaces at reaction temperatures, to evaluate vacancy formation energies and the free energy change for the RDS as a function of hydrogen coverages from structures obtained at reaction temperatures. Our methodology not only advances the understanding of ammonia synthesis via the associative MvK reaction pathway on Ni-supported transition metal nitrides but also provides a framework applicable to other supported metal catalysts. 2 Methodology 2.1 Density functional theory calculations We performed first-principle periodic DFT calculations on the highly symmetric B1-structured transition metal nitrides (MnN, TaN, VN, NbN, TiN, ScN, ZrN, and HfN) and rare-earth metal nitrides (CeN and YN). Further details about the metal nitride structures are included in the Supporting Information . The (100) surface facet of MnN was chosen for further study based on the low vacancy formation energy and surface free energy, along with its potential as a chemical looping agent, as discussed in detail in Section 3.1 [35,73]. The surface free energy (SFE) of a particular facet was calculated as: (1) SFE = E ( s l a b ) - N S N B × E ( b u l k ) 2 × S A slab where E ( s l a b ) represents the potential energy of the slab, E ( b u l k ) represents the potential energy of the bulk, N S and N B are the number of atoms in the slab and bulk respectively, and S A slab represents the surface area of the slab. The θ -phase MnN (mp-6933) structure, belonging to the Fm 3 ¯ m space group was obtained from the Materials Project database (version v2025.02.12) [74–78]. The lattice parameters of the bulk metal nitride were relaxed by sampling the Brillouin zone using a 5 x 5 x 5 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid. The DFT-calculated bulk lattice constant (a = 4.14 Å) was found to be within 1.66 % of the experimental lattice constant (a = 4.21 Å) [79]. We used the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) to construct p(3x2) supercells from the primitive unit cell for the (100) slab in a box with 20 Å in z-direction to prevent any interaction between the periodic slab images, as shown in Fig. 1 (a-c) [80]. The slabs were modeled with 3 bi-layers, resulting in 6 layers in total (consisting of 144 atoms in total, with a slab thickness of 13.16 Å), with four bottom layers kept fixed to simulate the bulk lattice spacing. The top two layers were allowed to fully relax during the geometry optimization calculations. The Brillouin zone of the slabs was sampled using a 3 x 3 x 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid. The Ni nanoparticle on the MnN (100) catalyst was modeled using a quasi-one-dimensional Ni nanowire on the planar surface of the MnN (100) slab, as shown in Fig. 1 (d-f). The size of the unit cell for Ni- MnN (100) was set based on the optimized p(3x2) MnN (100) structure, with the y-direction lattice constant being 8.28 Å. To construct the nanowire model, we selected a Ni surface that provides Ni–Ni atomic spacing closely matching the Mn–Mn distance of 4.14 Å, thereby keeping the epitaxial strain within 3 %. We evaluated the Ni (100), (110), and (111) surfaces, and found that the (110) and (111) surfaces exhibit Ni–Ni spacings of approximately 4.25 Å, corresponding to an epitaxial strain of 2.7 % prior to ground-state optimization ( Fig. S2 ). Thus, a Ni nanowire with a three layer thickness and one/two atom width (consisting of 12 atoms in total) and a nanowire thickness of 4.81 Å was constructed from an optimized Ni (110) surface. Post ground-state optimization, the Ni-Ni atomic distance (4.13 Å) was found to be within 0.25 % of the Mn-Mn atomic distance (4.14 Å), resulting in an epitaxial strain of 0.04 % and validating our choice for choosing this 12-atom nanowire model among other nanowire models based on low epitaxial strain ( Fig. S3 ). The top two layers of the MnN (100) slab along with the Ni (110) nanowire were allowed to fully relax during the geometry optimization calculations. The Brillouin zone of the Ni-MnN (100) model was sampled using a 2 x 3 x 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid. The DFT calculations were performed with Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package 6.4 (VASP 6.4) using the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [81–85]. Total energies were self-consistently calculated with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [86]. All calculations were spin polarized unless stated otherwise. The core states of atoms were represented using PAW PBE pseudopotentials [83,87]. The plane-wave basis set was constructed using an energy cutoff of 500 eV, total energy convergence of 10-5 eV, total force convergence of 0.05 eV Å-1, and a smearing width of 0.01 eV. The surface N vacancy formation energy (VFE), and the adsorption energy of the adsorbate X (X = H2, N2) on the surface were calculated as follows: (2) VFE = E ( d e f e c t / s l a b ) + 1 2 × E N 2 ( g ) - E s l a b (3) E a d s ( X ) = E X s l a b - E s l a b - E X g where E(X/slab) is the total energy of the adsorbed species X on the slab, Eslab is the total energy of the slab and EX(g) is the total energy of the adsorbate X in the gas phase. The intrinsic activation energy barriers and the transition states were identified using the climbing-image nudged elastic band method between the initial and final states [88–90]. The images were optimized to a total force convergence of 0.03 eV Å-1. The optimized transition states were checked with a vibrational mode analysis by searching for a single imaginary vibrational frequency. The Gibbs free energy of all the reaction species were calculated at the reaction temperature using a vibrational frequency analysis. The change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of a reaction species with respect to the initial state in the reaction was computed as follows: (4) Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E - T × Δ S where ΔE is the change in DFT calculated potential energy, ΔZPE is the change in zero point energy (calculated using the DFT-computed vibrational frequencies), T is the reaction temperature, and ΔS is the change in the entropy. For the reaction steps involving gaseous species, the rotational, transitional, and vibrational partition functions are considered when calculating the entropy. When considering the reaction steps involving the adsorption of closed-shell molecules directly onto the surface (*#N2 and *NH3), the entropy of these adsorbates is calculated through the Campbell Sellers equation: [91] (5) S ad 0 T = 0.70 × S gas 0 T - 3.3 × R where S ad 0 is the entropy of the adsorbed gas molecule on the surface, S gas 0 is the total gas phase entropy at temperature T, and R is the Gas constant. In the case of adsorbates strongly bound to the surface (species involving lattice N such as *N, *NH, and *NH2), the adsorbate entropy is calculated using the harmonic oscillator approximation by considering only the vibrational frequency modes (the translational and rotational modes not being considered). However, in the case of weakly bound open-shell molecular fragment adsorbates, the Campbell Sellers equation cannot be applied. The low frequency modes of *NNH and *NNH2 display vibrations resembling frustrated two-dimensional translation. Similarly, in the case of #H, the surface diffusion energy barrier V 0 (over a distance of a = 2.38 Å) is found to be 0.26 eV, with the low frequency modes resembling frustrated two-dimensional translation. Thus, the entropy of these adsorbates (#H, *NNH, and *NNH2) is computed by assuming them to be 2D hindered translator modes, with the lowest two modes assumed to be the frustrated translation modes, added with the harmonic oscillator entropy for the 3n-2 modes, and the 2D translational entropy calculated using the Sackur-Tetrode equation: [70,92–95] (6) S 2 D T r a n s l a t i o n 0 T = 2 3 18.6 × R + R × l n m m Ar 1.5 T 298.15 2.5 (7) q HO = e h υ 2 k B T e h υ k B T - 1 3 n - 2 υ x = V 0 2 m a 2 u = V 0 2 k B T (8) q XY = 2 π k B T L 2 h 2 × e - 2 u × I 0 2 u × h υ x k B T 2 × e h υ x 2 k B T e h υ x k B T - 1 2 (9) Q = q HO × q XY N ! N (10) S ad 0 T = S 2 D T r a n s l a t i o n 0 T + k B × T × ∂ l n Q ∂ T + l n Q where S 2 D T r a n s l a t i o n 0 is the 2D translational entropy calculated using the Sackur-Tetrode equation, m is the atomic mass of the adsorbate, m Ar is the atomic mass of Argon, h is Planck’s constant, k B is Boltzmann constant, υ is the harmonic vibrational frequency mode, L is the length, υ x is the hindered translator low frequency mode, u is the dimensionless surface diffusion energy barrier, I 0 is the zeroth order modified Bessel function, and N is the Avogadro number. 2.2 Microkinetic modeling We employed mean-field microkinetic modeling (MKM) based on the DFT-derived Gibbs free energy values for each elementary step [94–100]. The rate constants were derived using transition state theory: (11) A o = k B T h (12) k = A o × e - Δ G ‡ k B T where k is the rate constant of an elementary step, A is the pre-exponential factor, and Δ G ‡ is the change in Gibbs free energy between the initial and transition state. The reverse rate constants were calculated from the equilibrium rate constants, ensuring thermodynamic consistency throughout the model. The adsorption and desorption rate constants were modeled from collision theory: (13) k Ads / D e s = σ A 2 π m k B T where k Ads / D e s is the rate constant for the adsorption/desorption step, σ is the sticking coefficient (assumed as 1), and A is the area of the active site. A dual-site microkinetic model was constructed for Ni- MnN (100) with the N vacancy active sites on the MnN (100) surface being denoted by “*” and the Ni (110) step active sites being denoted by “#”. The H2 species were observed to undergo dissociative adsorption solely at the # site, while NH3 species were observed to adsorb on the * site in first half of the reaction cycle, and # sites in second half of the reaction cycle. N2 was observed to simultaneously adsorb at the nanowire and nitride surface bridge, depicted as “#*”. The steady state coverages of the reaction intermediates were computed numerically under differential kinetic regime without product co-feeding (T = 350 °C, 10 bar H2, 1 bar N2, 0 bar NH3). The generalized Degree of Rate Control (DRC) framework was employed to identify kinetically relevant intermediates and transition states [101,102]. Additional details on the rate expressions and site balances are provided in the Supporting Information . 2.3 Ab initio molecular dynamics calculations The DFT based ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations for the pristine Ni-MnN (100) as well as the Ni-MnN (100) model with complete hydrogen coverage were performed on a plane-wave basis set constructed using a reduced energy cutoff of 400 eV, total energy convergence of 10-5 eV, total force convergence of 0.03 eV Å-1 and a smearing width of 0.01 eV for the equilibration runs, and using a reduced energy cutoff of 400 eV, total energy convergence of 10-4 eV, total force convergence of 0.03 eV Å-1 and a smearing width of 0.2 eV for the production runs. All other parameters were set at the same level of DFT theory as mentioned above. To maintain a balance between ab initio accuracy and the computational cost, the reduced energy cutoff, force convergence, and higher smearing width were used. A Nos e ́ -Hoover thermostat was used to simulate the NVT ensemble in the case of both the pristine Ni-MnN (100) and the Ni-MnN (100) with complete hydrogen coverage [103]. In the case of pristine Ni-MnN (100), a timestep of 3 fs was used, with the simulation being equilibrated for at least 6 ps (2000 timesteps) at 673 K, and the production run being performed for 24 ps (8000 timesteps) at 673 K. In the case of the Ni-MnN (100) with complete hydrogen coverage, a timestep of 0.5 fs was used in place of 3 ps (to capture the motion of the rapidly vibrating H atoms with higher accuracy), with the simulation being equilibrated for at least 5 ps (10000 timesteps) at 573 K, and the production run being performed for 5 ps (10000 timesteps) at 673 K. The relative interfacial area of the Ni nanoparticle on the surface was calculated by constructing a polygon from the Ni atoms in direct contact with the MnN (100) top layer (assuming a nearest neighbor cutoff of 1.0 Å) and computing the area of the polygon. The average coordination number for the Ni nanowire was determined by calculating the coordination number of each Ni atom (using a nearest neighbor cutoff of 3.0 Å) and then averaging these values over all Ni atoms. The radial distribution function (RDF) was computed by obtaining the interatomic distance between atomic species, with a radial bin width of 0.05 Å and bin distances from 0 to 8 Å. The RDF curves were then normalized by the shell volume and bulk density and represent the averaged local coordination environment. 2.4 Machine learning interatomic potentials The machine learning interatomic potentials (MLPs) were generated using the Neural Equivariant Interatomic Potentials (NequIP) package [104–106]. The training and validation data for the MLPs were generated by sampling datapoints from the AIMD trajectories. The models were trained on the total energy, atomic forces, atomic positions, chemical symbols, and total stress, which were obtained from the vasprun.xml output files. In the case of the pristine Ni-MnN (100) model, we utilized 4000 images by sampling an image from the AIMD simulation for every 6 fs (2 timesteps). Similarly, in the case of the Ni-MnN (100) model with complete hydrogen coverage, we utilized 3334 images by sampling an image from the AIMD simulation for every 1.5 fs (3 timesteps). In both cases, the total number of images was randomly shuffled and then split into a training set with 80 % of the images and a validation set with 20 % of the images, similar to previous studies [72,104]. The neural network model consisted of four interaction blocks that iteratively update a 64-dimensional atomic feature representation. Initial edge features were constructed using invariant radial functions via a two-body embedding network with 80 neurons per radial layer. A radial cutoff of 6.5 Å was employed, using 10 basis functions along with spherical harmonics up to rotational order 2 to encode angular information. We used cosine annealing with warm restarts to adjust the learning rate during training, starting at 0.01 with a cycle length of 35 epochs, and trained the model over a total of 140 epochs, i.e. 4 learning cycles. Our loss function comprised the per-species force predictions, stress predictions, and per-atom total energy predictions, with the force loss weighted 20 times and the stress loss weighted 50 times more than the energy loss. This configuration enabled the network to produce physically consistent predictions for forces, energies, and stress. The NequIP machine learning interatomic potentials trained on the AIMD trajectories were deployed in the LAMMPS package to perform classical MD using the machine learning force field parameters, here forth denoted as MLMD [107,108]. The simulations were carried out for 250 ps (500000 timesteps) using a timestep of 0.5 fs, with the remaining parameters set to match the AIMD parameters as closely as possible. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface modeling of Ni-supported metal nitride catalysts We begin by identifying the low free energy surface terminations for the B1-MNs via a surface free energy analysis on the low-index (100), (110), and (111) surface facets ( Fig. S4 ). Our results indicate that the (100) surface exhibits the lowest surface free energy, and based on Wulff construction, it is the highest surface area facet on supported nanoparticle catalysts. Since vacancy formation plays a crucial role in the activation of N2 in the associative MvK mechanism, we use VFE as a reaction descriptor to identify the transition metal nitride for our study. We calculated the vacancy formation energy for the (100) surface facet of the B1-MNs, as shown in Fig. 2 (a), and found MnN (100) to exhibit the lowest vacancy formation energy of 1.11 eV, closely followed by CeN (100) and TaN (100) with a vacancy formation energy of 1.13 eV and 1.18 eV respectively. Laassiri et al. have shown that manganese nitride-based materials, such as Li-Mn-N can effectively transfer the lattice nitrogen as a result of the high lattice N mobility, while Michalsky et al. demonstrated that metal nitride catalysts can regenerate the surface N vacancies via reversible phase transitions under varying temperature and pressure conditions, a phenomena known as chemical looping [35,73,109]. The low vacancy formation energy of MnN (100) combined with the potential for facile vacancy regeneration via chemical looping, and its tunability to accommodate metal nanoparticles strongly motivates our choice of MnN (100) for further investigation into ammonia synthesis via the associative MvK mechanism. While N2 activation in the associative MvK reaction takes place through the formation of surface vacancies on MnN (100), the activation of H2 can occur through direct dissociative adsorption on the surface Mn or N atom. Recently, Qu et al. reported the dissociative adsorption of H2 on the MnN0.43 ( 1 1 ¯ 0 ) surface to occur on the Mn atom through a negligible intrinsic activation energy barrier, resulting in dissociated H atoms occupying the Mn-Mn bridge sites [38]. In the case of MnN (100), we observed that H2 does not undergo dissociative adsorption on the surface Mn atom. This could be attributed to the surface Mn atom in MnN (100) being surrounded by four N and four Mn atoms in the top layer, with a coordination number of 8 atoms which could signify a saturated bonding state of the Mn d-orbitals, and lower reactivity of the surface Mn atom. In contrast, surfaces with lower atomic coordination numbers such as MnN0.43 ( 1 1 ¯ 0 ) allow for H2 dissociation. Recently, Ye et al. demonstrated that the activation of H2 on rock salt structured rare earth metal nitride (001) surfaces can be facilitated using Ni nanoclusters, due to its low affinity for nitrogen and high affinity for hydrogen [32]. Here we investigated H2 activation via a quasi-one-dimensional Ni nanowire on the MnN (100) support. We observed that H2 undergoes dissociative adsorption on the Ni nanowire via a negligible intrinsic activation energy barrier – supporting the spontaneous dissociation of H2 on the Ni nanowire model. Additionally, we investigated the change in VFE due to the presence of the Ni nanowire on MnN (100). We identified two N vacancy sites, as shown in Fig. 2 (b), with the site closer to the nanowire being denoted as Vclose and the site farther from the nanowire being denoted as Vfar. The VFE of Vclose was found to be 0.80 eV, while the VFE of Vfar was found to be 0.92 eV, with both of the VFEs being lower compared to the VFE of 1.11 eV on the pristine MnN (100). We attribute this reduction in VFE to the strong metal-support interaction in Ni-MnN (100) with the excess electrons from the surface N vacancy moving into the Ni 3d orbitals, leading to stabilization of the metal-support structure. This phenomenon is analogous to that observed in the Ni8-LaN (001) catalyst reported by Ye et al. [32,33]. 3.2 Thermodynamic and kinetic analysis of Ni-MnN (100) To gain molecular-level insights into the associative MvK mechanism of Ni-MnN (100) for ammonia synthesis at mild temperatures, we performed a Gibbs free energy analysis for the Ni-MnN (100) catalyst at 350 °C, as shown in Fig. 3 and detailed in the Supporting Information ( Fig. S5 , Table S1 and S2 ). Our initial configuration consists of the Ni-MnN (100) catalyst along with three H2 molecules and one N2 molecule. We found that H2 undergoes dissociative adsorption on the Ni nanowire step site (I → II) through a negligible intrinsic activation energy barrier, with each H atom occupying a Ni edge site (denoted as “#”). The formation of lattice N vacancy sites (denoted as “*”) can proceed via sequential hydrogenation of the lattice N atom. Thus, the first hydrogenation of the lattice N occurs via migration of the H atom on the Ni edge site to the closest lattice N atom to form a *NH moiety (II → III), occurring via an intrinsic activation energy barrier of 1.23 eV. This is followed by migration of the remaining H atom on the Ni edge site to the *NH site to form *NH2 (III → IV), proceeding through a similar intrinsic activation energy barrier of 1.22 eV. The *NH2 moiety is observed to occupy a Mn-Mn bridge site, to enhance its steric freedom. The dissociative adsorption of the second H2 occurs on the Ni nanowire, resulting in the formation of two #H species (IV → V). The third hydrogenation of the lattice N occurs via migration of the H from the Ni step site to form *NH3 (V → VI) through an intrinsic activation energy barrier of 1.51 eV. The NH3 is spontaneously released from the N vacancy site and adsorbs onto the surface Mn atom in an inverted orientation such that the N lone pair directly interacts with the Mn atom. The first half of the reaction cycle ends with spontaneous NH3 desorption via a negligible intrinsic activation energy barrier, resulting in the formation of a surface N vacancy (VI → VII) which is endergonic by 0.14 eV. We then observed that N2 adsorption occurs at the surface N vacancy site (VII → VIII), with one N forming a weakly interacting bond with the Ni while the other N adsorbs on the edge of the surface Mn atom next to the vacancy. The adsorption energy of this N2 on nanowire configuration is found to be exothermic (−0.19 eV) while the configuration with the N2 being adsorbed directly on the nanowire is found to be endothermic (0.21 eV), indicating that the system energetically favors N2 adsorption in the surface N vacancy over adsorption on the nanowire itself ( Fig. S6 ). Previous studies have highlighted the adsorption of N2 on the surface N vacancy site on rare earth metal nitride (001) supported Ni catalyst to proceed in an end-on configuration, and the adsorption of N2 on the surface N vacancy site on MnN0.43 ( 1 1 ¯ 0 ) to proceed in a Mn-Mn bridge site configuration over the vacancy site [32,38]. We attribute this change to the coordination environment of the surface N vacancy – in the case of rare earth metal nitrides, the N vacancy is surrounded by four metal atoms, resulting in the formation of a four-fold hollow site while in the case of MnN0.43 ( 1 1 ¯ 0 ) the N vacancy is surrounded by two Mn atoms, resulting in the formation of a bridge site configuration. In our case, while the surface N vacancy is surrounded by four Mn atoms, the close proximity of the Ni edge atom on the nanowire facilitates the adsorption of N2 such that the top N atom weakly interacts with the Ni atom while the bottom N atom interacts with the lattice Mn atom adjacent to the vacancy. In the second half of the reaction, adsorbed N2 activation proceeds through sequential hydrogenation. The first hydrogenation of *#NN, resulting in the formation of *NNH (VIII → IX) occurs via the migration of H from the Ni edge site to the topmost N atom of *#NN, resulting in the shifting of *NNH species in an end-on configuration within the surface N vacancy site. This step proceeds via an intrinsic activation energy barrier of 1.73 eV. Notably, the nitrogen-nitrogen bond length is found to increase from 1.14 Å in *NN to 1.35 Å in *NNH, implying the weakening of the nitrogen-nitrogen bonding as a result of the hydrogenation. The H atoms on the Ni nanowire are replenished by the final dissociative adsorption of H2 on the Ni edge site (IX → X), followed by the migration of the H atom to the *NNH species to form *NNH2 (X → XI), which has an intrinsic activation energy barrier of 0.79 eV. The second hydrogenation of *NN, results in a further increase in the nitrogen-nitrogen bond length, from 1.35 Å to 1.51 Å, with the topmost N weakly interacting with the Ni atom. The final hydrogenation step of the reaction proceeds via migration of the remaining H atom from Ni to *NNH2 to form *NNH3 (XI → XII) which undergoes dissociation to generate *N and adsorb NH3 on the Ni nanowire via an intrinsic activation energy barrier of 0.04 eV. The reaction cycle ends with the desorption of NH3 from the Ni nanowire to replenish the surface N vacancy (XII → XIII) which is endergonic by 0.19 eV. We performed a kinetic assessment of the reaction cycle under differential kinetic regime with a dual active site microkinetic model, as described in Section 2.2 and the Supporting Information . For a serial mechanism at differential conversion, we computed the steady state coverages of the reaction intermediates and subsequently the reaction rates numerically, observing the * site being completely covered by *N at steady state, depicting the replenishing of lattice N at end of the reaction cycle, and the # site being completely covered by #H, depicting the complete hydrogenation of the nanowire. The steady state ammonia turnover frequency was calculated as ≈ 1.13 x 10-10 turnovers/site/second, highlighting a low TOF and reaction rate for the system ( Fig. S7 ), also corroborated by the calculated apparent activation energy of 186.97 kJ/mol or 1.94 eV ( Fig. S8 ). We found that the N2 reaction order for NH3 synthesis on Ni-MnN (100) is ≈ 0.37 and the H2 reaction order is ≈ 1.03. Previous studies on dissociative ammonia synthesis mechanism via Fe-based and Ru-based catalysts have reported a higher reaction order of N2 compared to that of H2, signifying the N ≡ N triple bond dissociation as the rate determining step [110,111]. Recent studies on associative ammonia synthesis via Mars-van Krevelen mechanism have reported N2 and H2 reaction orders of 0.6 and 1.7 respectively in pristine metal nitrides, and 1.1 and 1.4 respectively in supported metal nitrides [32,38]. The generalized Degree of Rate Control (DRC) analysis (Table 1 ) identifies the *NNH formation (VIII → IX) as the rate determining step (RDS), as it exhibits the highest DRC value of 0.77. This assignment is consistent with the results of our microkinetic model, where the higher reaction order with respect to H2 compared to N2 further supports an associative Mars–van Krevelen mechanism for ammonia synthesis. Thus, in the hypothesized associative MvK mechanism for ammonia synthesis, the reaction proceeds through a sequential series of hydrogenation steps, without any significant competing parallel pathways. Our analysis establishes that hydrogenation at the TM-MN interface is kinetically relevant for predicting apparent activation energies. These interfacial sites were identified based on a 0 K energy optimization, but prior studies have provided evidence that reaction temperatures may restructure these interfaces [58,59,61]. We next turn to AIMD approaches to quantify interface restructuring at ammonia synthesis temperatures. 3.3 Supported nanowire interfaces at reaction temperature 3.3.1 Morphological evolution of Ni-MnN (100) using AIMD While the Ni-MnN (100) structure obtained from ground-state DFT at 0 K provided ammonia synthesis reaction orders and a high apparent activation energy of reaction, this static model inherently assumes a catalyst structure with symmetrical active sites. Recently, Lin et al. explored the thermally induced reverse sintering phenomenon of Ni nanoparticles on γ-Mo2N catalyst using AIMD − observing the restructuring of the nanoparticles into under-coordinated two dimensional clusters which enhanced the catalytic selectivity for the CO2 hydrogenation to CO reaction [64]. To account for the temperature-induced reconstruction of the Ni nanowire active sites, we performed AIMD simulations to investigate the dynamic structural evolution of the Ni-MnN (100) structure at 400 °C (mild temperature condition in ammonia synthesis), as described in Section 2.3 . We interrogated the kinetic implications of active site reconstruction on key reaction energetics by analysing transient Ni active site configurations. We performed AIMD for the Ni nanowire along with the MnN (100) layers for 30 ps as illustrated in Fig. 4 (a) – with the first 6 ps being the equilibration run, and the following 24 ps being the production run. To quantify the restructuring of the Ni nanowire on the MnN (100) surface, we implemented the relative interfacial area of the system as a putative order parameter. The relative interfacial area of the Ni–MnN (100) system was measured as the area of the polygon constructed from the Ni atoms directly in contact with the MnN (100) surface, as detailed in the Section 2.3 . We observed that the Ni nanowire undergoes atomic rearrangement to increase its interfacial area, resulting in a higher potential energy, as seen in Fig. 4 (b-c). At 10 ps, the Ni nanowire reconstructs by reducing its layers from 3 to 2, which increases its width from 2.60 Å to 3.66 Å and expands its interfacial area from 7 Å2 to 11.34 Å2, and by 30 ps, the nanowire evolves into a nearly symmetrical configuration with an interfacial area of 13.56 Å2 − almost double its initial value. Subsequent DFT optimization of the AIMD-reconstructed nanowire results in a new equilibrium configuration where the Ni nanowire adopts a two-layer structure with a width of 3.19 Å and exhibits negligible epitaxial strain (0.26 %), along with the formation of new Ni edge atom active sites, which can influence H2 activation. To further assess the influence of nanowire restructuring on the catalytic performance, we calculated the VFE for the nearest surface nitrogen vacancy. The resulting 0.70 eV VFE is lower than the previously determined 0.80 eV VFE – suggesting that the dynamic restructuring of the Ni nanowire active sites not only facilitates H2 activation, but also facilitates the formation of reactive nitrogen vacancies, a key catalytic descriptor for promoting the associative MvK mechanism in ammonia synthesis. To overcome the timescale limitations of AIMD and sample from an equilibrium distribution of nanowires at extended timescales, we trained machine learning potentials (MLPs) on the AIMD data for Ni-MnN (100) at 400 °C, as mentioned in Section 2.4 and as detailed in the Supporting Information ( Figs. S9, S10 and S11 ). This enabled us to generate machine learning force fields (MLFFs), which were then deployed in the LAMMPS package to perform classical MD on the Ni-MnN (100) system at mild temperature conditions, hereby referred to as MLMD (machine learning molecular dynamics) over a timescale of 250 ps, allowing us to perform an extensive sampling of the Ni nanowire configurational space. 3.3.2 Extended nanowire structural evolution using MLMD To benchmark the size-extensivity of our nanowire MLP in predicting Ni coordination environments we performed MLMD on three different systems at 350 °C ( Fig. S12 ) – the original Ni nanowire on the p(3x2x3) MnN (100) surface (156 atoms in total) shown in Fig. 5 (a) which was used in the training set, a broader nanowire on a p(6x2x3) supercell of the MnN (100) model (312 atoms in total) as shown in Fig. 5 (b), and an isolated nanowire on a p(3x4x3) supercell of the MnN (100) model (312 atoms in total) as shown in Fig. 5 (c). In all three cases, the nanowire models exhibit only minor fluctuations in their average potential energy over 250 ps. We monitored the relative interfacial area between the Ni nanowire and the MnN (100) support, as well as the average coordination number of the Ni nanowire (using a 3 Å nearest-neighbor cutoff), to capture changes in morphology and atomic connectivity (see Section 2.3 for details). To validate our MLP training outside of the initial training and validation set, we compared atomic forces on 100 randomly selected configurations from the MLMD trajectories with DFT single-point calculations, finding mean absolute errors of 0.11 eV/Å for the smaller nanowire, 0.12 eV/Å for the broader nanowire, and 0.15 eV/Å for the isolated nanowire detailed in the Supporting Information ( Figs. S13, S14 and S15 ). Based on the similarity in mean absolute force errors between the small, broad and isolated nanowires, we infer that our model is sufficiently accurate to predict fluxionality changes at finite temperatures. We observed that the smaller nanowire undergoes reconstruction in MLMD from 3-layers to 2-layers, accompanied by an increase in its width from 2.56 Å to 3.73 Å, and a corresponding expansion in the relative interfacial area from 7.00 Å 2 to 12.47 Å 2 over the 250 ps simulation ( Supplementary Movie S1 in the associated Zenodo repository). This structural evolution parallels the AIMD observations in Section 3.3 , emphasizing that even at 350 °C, mild thermal activation can cause active site restructuring. However, in case of the broader nanowire system – initially composed of two adjacent nanowires on the support – the nanowires were observed to aggregate into a single nanowire over the 250 ps simulation ( Supplementary Movie S2 in the associated Zenodo repository). Such aggregation is usually thermodynamically driven to reduce the overall surface free energy, similar to established sintering mechanisms where neighboring metal clusters merge via atomic diffusion and neck formation [54,112–114]. The proximity of the two nanowires increases the tendency of our system for aggregation, as only minimal atomic migration is needed to bridge the gap between nanowires. Notably, in case of the non-periodic nanowire system, the nanowire initially undergoes active site restructuring analogous to the smaller nanowire, however after 250 ps, the formation of a nanocluster is observed, resembling a pyramid-like Ni(111) structure at the end of the simulation ( Supplementary Movie S3 in the associated Zenodo repository). Fig. 6 (a) reveals that the relative interfacial area of the broader nanowire system does not undergo major fluctuations, while the relative interfacial area of the nanoparticle increases from 7.00 Å 2 to 15.11 Å 2 over the 250 ps simulation indicating the formation of a nanocluster. By tracking the average coordination number of the nanowire systems as a function of time as seen in Fig. 6 (b), we observed that the average coordination number of the broader nanowire system fluctuates around a value of ≈ 8.5 over 250 ps of the simulation, signifying the aggregation of the smaller nanowires into a larger nanowire and reflecting a bulk-like coordination environment for the Ni atoms. On the contrary, the average coordination number for the smaller nanowire system was observed to increase its mean coordination number from ≈ 7.5 around 15 ps to a value of ≈ 7.8 by end of the 250 ps simulation, signifying the reconstruction of the smaller nanowire system to increase its average coordination number. This trend is also observed in case of the isolated nanowire system, with the average coordination number being low initially due to lack of periodicity in the nanowire but increasing its mean fluctuation from ≈ 6.8 to ≈ 7.1 over the course of 250 ps, representative of its self-aggregation tendency. As seen in Fig. 6 (c), the Ni-Ni radial distribution function (RDF) plot indicates the presence of three sharp peaks at a coordination shell radius of 2.5 Å for the smaller nanowire, broader nanowire and the isolated nanowire cases. The lowest RDF peak representing the lowest Ni atom density in the coordination shell is associated with the smaller nanowire model since it restructures to decrease the number of layers and increase the width, while the highest RDF peak indicating the highest Ni atom density in the coordination shell is associated with the isolated nanowire model, representative of the nanocluster formation. This phenomenon aligns with the well-known reactivity trends in nanoparticle systems: smaller clusters with lower coordination numbers tend to be highly reactive but also, more prone to sintering. Conversely, as nanoparticles grow larger or merge, their coordination numbers increase, which can reduce the reactivity while stabilizing the structure against further morphological changes. Thus, although the final single nanowire formed from the broader nanowire is less dispersed, it is thermodynamically more stable at 350 °C, indicating the restructuring and deactivating of metal nanowires via aggregation. In addition to these morphological changes, we observed distinct differences in the interfacial sites between the smaller, broader and isolated nanowire systems. In the smaller nanowire, structural rearrangement increased its width, expanding the area of the MnN (100) surface that is covered and exposing more undercoordinated active sites. The broader nanowire system underwent aggregation, leading to the formation of a larger nanowire that effectively doubled the number of interfacial active sites; however, these sites remained distributed over an area similar to that of the individual nanowires prior to aggregation. In contrast, the isolated nanowire system underwent cluster formation to form a pyramid-like nanocluster, exposing a high number of uncoordinated step and kink sites, that contribute to its high reactivity. While these models have focused on the temperature-induced interfacial restructuring on clean nanowires, at reaction conditions it is likely that a steady-state coverage of hydrogen is prevalent due to the observed facile dissociative adsorption. We next turn our interfacial TM-MN modeling towards nanowire sites at finite hydrogen coverages. 3.3.3 Supported nanowire structures at finite hydrogen coverages and reaction temperatures We next adsorbed hydrogen to our supported nanowires to quantify reconstruction as a function of hydrogen coverage. We performed AIMD simulations on the Ni-MnN (100) system with 1 ML (8 hydrogen atoms per unit cell) coverage at 400 °C for 10 ps – with the first 5 ps being the equilibration run and the next 5 ps being the production run, as detailed in Section 2.3 and the Supporting Information ( Fig. S16 ). Subsequently, we trained a MLFF for the 1.0 ML hydrogen-covered nanowire, trained on the AIMD production run simulations at 400 °C, as detailed in Section 2.4 and the Supporting Information ( Figs. S17 and S18 ). We explored the MLMD runs on Ni-MnN (100) with 0.25H coverage, 0.50H coverage, 0.75H coverage, and complete H coverage, as seen in Fig. 7 (a-d). To validate our MLP training outside of the training and validation set, we compared atomic forces on 100 randomly selected configurations from the MLMD trajectories with DFT single-point calculations. The resulting mean absolute errors were 0.14 eV/Å for the 0.25H coverage case, and 0.13 eV/Å for the 0.50H coverage, 0.75H coverage, and the fully H covered systems, as detailed in the Supporting Information ( Figs. S19, S20, S21 and S22 ). Based on the similarity in mean absolute force errors between the various H coverage models, we infer that our model is sufficiently accurate to predict fluxionality changes at finite temperatures and different adsorbate coverages, enabling us to explore dynamic restructuring of the active sites under temperature and coverage conditions. The transferability of our potential from high to low coverage reflects the interpolation of configurations based on the high coverage training data. By training on the 1.0 ML surface, the Ni-Ni, Ni-H, and H-H interactions regressed from the network are inclusive of the interactions observed at sub-monolayer coverages. The similarity in validation loss of the sub-monolayer models in addition to the stability of these simulations indicates that coverage-dependence is one property where force field transferability is expected, even for small models such as those developed here. From the MLMD trajectories at 350 °C, we observed that varying hydrogen coverage on the Ni nanowire results in distinct restructuring behaviors. In the 0.25 H coverage system (2 H atoms), the H atoms migrate from a single Ni edge site to a three-fold site that bridges two Ni terrace atoms and one Ni step atom ( Supplementary Movie S4 in the associated Zenodo repository). The nanowire undergoes structural rearrangements as a Ni terrace atom shifts positions, leading to the formation of an asymmetrical nanowire. In the 0.50 H coverage system (4 H atoms), H atoms initially adsorb onto step sites on one side of the nanowire ( Supplementary Movie S5 in the associated Zenodo repository). Over 250 ps, the H atoms migrate to three-fold sites, similar to the 0.25 H case, and ultimately disperse to the opposite side, forming a symmetric configuration with minimal net movement of Ni atoms. As the H coverage is increased to 0.75 H (6 H atoms), we observed the stabilization of localized pockets of hydrogen at undercoordinated top sites, pushing Ni atoms along the wire perimeter in addition to the typical migration into three-fold sites – resulting in the formation of a symmetrical nanowire ( Supplementary Movie S6 in the associated Zenodo repository). At full H coverage (8 H atoms), we observe an expansion in certain regions of the nanowire, which could be attributed to high hydrogen loading that significantly lowers the diffusion barriers for Ni surface atoms and improves the driving force for restructuring, with H atoms occupying both three-fold and undercoordinated Ni sites ( Supplementary Movie S7 in the associated Zenodo repository). At full H coverage, we do not observe the H atom spillover from the nanowire onto the surface due to the presence of a high thermodynamic barrier, as detailed in the Supporting Information ( Fig. S23 ). Notably, Ni atoms in the lowest layer, which are in direct contact with the MnN (100) surface, remain largely immobile for all H coverage cases, supported by the fluctuation of the relative interfacial area around a constant value ( ≈ 7.9 Å2), as shown in Fig. 8 (a). Our results show that varying the H coverage induces fluxional behavior in the Ni nanowire, leading to the formation of distinct TM-MN interfacial active sites. The H-H RDF plot, as shown in Fig. 8 (b) demonstrates the peak shift and broadening across different H coverages. For 0.25 ML hydrogen, a singular sharp peak is observed at 3.6 Å, associated with the presence of just two H atoms on the nanowire, however in case of 0.50H coverage, we observe a reduced peak at 3.5 Å and the presence of a smaller peak at 5.1 Å, attributed to the distribution of H atoms on both sides of the nanowires. At 0.75H coverage, two broad peaks of nearly same height are observed at 2.6 Å and 3.4 Å respectively with the presence of a smaller peak at 5.2 Å, attributed to the distribution of H atoms on the sides of the nanowire as well as the top site of the nanowire resulting in a uniform distribution of H atoms along the nanowire. At full H coverage, a sharper first peak at 2.5 Å, reduced peak at 3.3 Å, and broader peak at 4.8 Å are observed, highlighting the densely populated Ni nanowire with H atoms at three-fold and undercoordinated Ni sites. Thus, we see that as the H coverage is increased on the Ni nanowire, peaks are observed at lower distances, eventually resulting in peak broadening to account for the correlated H atom distributions at higher H coverages. Additionally, we also tested the effect of surface N defects across all four H coverage cases and observed that the nanowire does not undergo morphological restructuring due to the presence of surface N defect as detailed in the Supplementary Information ( Fig. S24 ). We next evaluated the kinetic implications of active site restructuring on reaction energetics, computing the vacancy formation energy (VFE) for the DFT-optimized H-coverage structures, focusing on distinct surface N vacancy sites near the Ni nanowires, as shown in Fig. 8 (c-f). For the 0.25H coverage system, the nanowire underwent reconstruction into an asymmetric configuration, characterized by the under-coordinated terrace Ni atoms. We computed the VFE at two distinct sites: site V1, located near a non-defected region, exhibited a VFE of 0.59 eV, whereas site V2, found near the defected region, had a VFE of 0.91 eV. In contrast, for the systems with 0.50 to 1.00H coverage, the nanowire retained a symmetrical configuration, and the vacancy sites showed similar VFEs of approximately 0.84 eV (V3 and V4) and 0.86 eV (V5). The uniform VFEs in these cases can be attributed to the consistent coordination environment provided by the symmetrical nanowire structure. When compared to other computational models in our study (Table 2 ), we observed that the Ni– MnN (100) model with 0.25H coverage exhibited the lowest VFE overall. Notably, this was the only nanowire model in our study which had an asymmetrical nanowire structure with undercoordinated Ni atoms – signifying that the Ni nanowire coordination environment facilitates surface N vacancy formation. In Section 3.2 , we identified the *NNH formation (VIII → IX) as the rate determining step (RDS) for the pristine Ni-MnN (100) model at 350 °C. To assess the free energy change associated with *NNH formation at 350 °C for the restructured Ni-MnN (100) model under different H coverages, we chose the surface N vacancy site for each H coverage model with the lowest VFE – V1 for 0.25 ML, V3 for 0.50 ML, V4 for 0.75 ML and V5 for 1.00 ML. As detailed in the Supporting Information ( Fig. S25 and Table S3 ), we observed that the *NN and *NNH adsorption configurations differ from the original Ni-MnN (100) configuration. Under H coverage conditions, the N2 adsorbs in a bridge site configuration over the vacancy site to form *NN configuration, with the hydrogenation causing the *NNH configuration to be adsorbed partially into the vacancy. As seen in Fig. 9 , we observe that the free energy change associated with the RDS, i.e. Δ G‡ decreases from 2.40 eV for the 0.25 ML model to 1.01 eV for 0.50 ML, 0.95 eV for 0.75 ML and 0.87 eV for 1.00 ML models. Additionally, we calculated the Ni d-Band Center and Ni p-Band Center for the H coverage models. We found that as the H coverage increases, the Ni d-Band Center undergoes minimal changes, whereas the Ni p-Band Center decreases from −2.92 eV for 0.25 ML model to −3.68 eV for the 1.00 ML model, highlighting a strong correlation between Δ G‡ and the Ni p-Band Center. We hypothesize that as the H coverage on the Ni nanowire increases, the number of Ni p-orbitals hybridized by H 1 s-orbitals increases, leading to a Ni nanowire with less bonding orbitals, which in turn lowers the binding strength of the adsorbates – subsequently resulting in the reduction of Δ G‡ across different H coverages on the Ni-MnN (100) model. We note in passing that at 350 °C, the Δ G‡ for the restructured Ni–MnN (100) model under full H coverage is 0.87 eV—substantially lower than the 1.73 eV calculated for the original Ni–MnN (100) model, demonstrating the efficacy of our integrated DFT-AIMD-MLMD approach in exploring active site ensembles in supported metal catalysts under reaction conditions and assessing their kinetic relevance. 4 Conclusions We investigated mild temperature ammonia synthesis via the associative Mars–van Krevelen mechanism on supported B1-structured metal nitride catalysts. Surface free energy analysis of low-index facets revealed that the (100) facet is the most stable due to its low surface free energy. MnN (100) was selected for further study based on its low vacancy formation energy (VFE) and its tunable metal–support interface properties. We then developed a dual active site catalyst by depositing a Ni nanowire onto the MnN (100) surface, with H2 and N2 activation occurring on the Ni nanowire and surface N vacancy sites respectively. A Gibbs free energy analysis at 623 K identified the *NNH formation step with the highest intrinsic activation energy barrier, and our dual site microkinetic model (MKM) under differential kinetic regime revealed an apparent activation energy of 1.94 eV and reaction orders of approximately 0.37 for N2 and 1.03 for H2. The Degree of Rate Control analysis unveiled the *NNH formation as the rate determining step (RDS), corroborating the presence of associative MvK mechanism in Ni-MnN (100). To capture the temperature-induced restructuring of transition metal – metal nitride active sites, we performed ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations on pristine Ni-MnN (100) and Ni-MnN (100) model with complete hydrogen coverage at 400 °C. These simulations revealed dynamic restructuring of the Ni nanowire to increase its interfacial area and the emergence of transient active sites and metastable isomers that are not observed in static 0 K DFT calculations. Recognizing the timescale limitations of AIMD, we trained machine learning potentials (MLPs) on our AIMD data. The resulting machine learning force fields (MLFFs) were deployed to perform machine learning molecular dynamics (MLMD) simulations over 250 ps. Our MLMD simulations revealed that while restructuring behavior in smaller nanowire is similar to the AIMD observation, and broader nanowire systems tend to aggregate into larger nanowires without major changes in the interfacial active sites, mirroring the sintering phenomena observed in larger nanoparticles, the isolated nanowire model tends to undergo morphological evolution to form a nanocluster. Additionally, we evaluated the sensitivity of the nanowire models to hydrogen coverage. At low hydrogen loading (0.25 ML), the nanowire adopts an asymmetrical configuration with undercoordinated Ni atoms, which lowers the VFE at adjacent surface N sites to 0.59 eV. In contrast, higher hydrogen coverages (0.50–1.00 ML) yield more symmetrical configurations with uniform VFEs in the range of 0.84–0.86 eV. We further performed free energy analyses of the RDS (*NNH formation) on the restructured Ni-MnN (100) models under different H coverages and observed that the free energy change for the RDS decreased systematically with increasing H coverage, from 2.40 eV at 0.25 ML to 0.87 eV at 1.00 ML. This decrease was correlated with a downward shift in the Ni p-Band Center, suggesting that increased hydrogen adsorption weakens adsorbate binding strength via hybridization with Ni p-orbitals. Our MLPs trained on high coverages were observed to predict sub-monolayer coverages at similar accuracy to high coverage providing evidence that MLPs can be used to study coverage-dependent catalyst fluxionality. Our integrated approach − combining static DFT, AIMD, and MLP provides a comprehensive framework for understanding the atomic-level interplay between metal–support interactions, active site fluxionality, and catalytic reactivity in Ni supported transition metal nitride catalyst for ammonia synthesis. The insights gained from studying the dynamic restructuring and hydrogen coverage effects on the Ni nanowire interface pave the way for refined free energy evaluations and microkinetic models that can more accurately capture reaction kinetics under reaction temperatures and adsorbate coverages. Broadly, our study enhances the fundamental understanding of dynamic catalyst behavior at reaction conditions, offering insights into the rational design of metal supported catalysts not only for ammonia synthesis, but for a wide range of reactions. coredata.dc:description: The development of energy-efficient catalysts for ammonia synthesis under mild conditions is crucial for reducing the energy demands and carbon footprint of the industrial Haber-Bosch process. In this study, we investigated ammonia synthesis via the associative Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism using B1-structured metal nitrides, focusing on manganese nitride (MnN) due to its low vacancy formation energy and potential as a metal-support interface. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations identified the MnN (100) facet as the most stable, with a nickel (Ni) nanowire implemented on the surface to facilitate H2 dissociation while surface nitrogen vacancies activate N2. A free energy diagram for Ni-MnN (100) at 350 °C was constructed and a dual-site microkinetic model was developed to determine reaction orders, apparent activation energies and the rate limiting step (RDS). To capture temperature-induced catalyst restructuring, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations and machine learning interatomic potentials (MLPs) were employed to improve the sampling of interfacial active sites over longer timescales. We found significant active site fluxionality leading to active site structural rearrangements that reduced vacancy formation energies. A hydrogen coverage analysis at reaction temperatures revealed coverage-dependent dynamic restructuring of Ni active sites, with lowered free energy change of the RDS that correlates with Ni p-Band center. MLPs were observed to predict coverage-dependent fluxionality with training data exclusive to high coverage regimes. By integrating DFT, AIMD, and MLP-based molecular dynamics, we established a computational framework for understanding dynamic metal-support interactions in transition metal nitride catalysts, demonstrating its applicability not only to ammonia synthesis under mild conditions but also to broader classes of supported catalysts and reactions.
